title: Fantasy football waiver wire: Rams' Gerald Everett a cure for bye-week blues?
text:
CLOSE Charles Curtis gives you four fantasy things to know for Week 6. USA TODAY

Does it seem like this is a terribly light week on the fantasy football waiver wire? Or are there just not enough startable players to go around? Fantasy teams' depth will be tested in Week 6 with the Bills, Bears, Colts and Raiders getting the week off.

Someone has to fill those open roster spots. Let's see who might be available.

Recommended bids based on a free agent acquisition budget (FAAB) of $100 for the season.

BEST BETS

TE Gerald Everett, Los Angeles Rams ($10). There weren’t many breakout performances in Week 5, but fantasy owners looking for a tight end may have found one in Everett. He had a season-high 136 receiving yards on Thursday night and has a total of 19 targets the past two weeks.

Rams tight end Gerald Everett had a career-high 136 receiving yards in Week 5 at Seattle. (Photo: Steven Bisig, USA TODAY Sports)

RB Chase Edmonds, Arizona Cardinals ($8). David Johnson owners would be wise to pick up his backup while he's still available. Edmonds had a surprising share of the backfield work on Sunday with eight carries for 68 yards and a TD, plus three catches for 14 more yards. If Johnson's back injury turns out to be something that has him at less than 100% this week, it may take twice as much to land Edmonds.

WR Zay Jones, Oakland Raiders ($6). There are still three weeks remaining until the NFL's trade deadline, but the Raiders and Buffalo Bills got an early start. Jones had only seven receptions in five weeks with the Bills, but a rash of injuries to Raiders receivers could open up some playing time in a better pass offense. No. 1 wideout Tyrell Williams was inactive last week with a foot injury, so opportunity could be knocking.

WR Darius Slayton, New York Giants ($6). The first-year wideout gave Daniel Jones another option in the passing game on Sunday by catching four of his five targets against the Vikings for 62 yards and a touchdown. If Sterling Shepard has to miss time with a concussion, Slayton's value takes a considerable jump.

Likely already on rosters (but check to be sure): WR Auden Tate, Cincinnati Bengals; TE Chris Herndon, New York Jets.

REPLACEMENTS

RB Jon Hilliman, New York Giants ($4). Likely a one-week play due to Wayne Gallman's concussion and Saquon Barkley's impending return, Hilliman could be a fantasy contributor based on volume alone. Just don't expect much production with the top-ranked New England Patriots defense up next on Thursday night.

QB Devlin Hodges, Pittsburgh Steelers ($3). With Mason Rudolph sustaining a concussion, Hodges was pressed into emergency duty on Sunday. Hodges played it safe, completing seven of his nine attempts for 68 yards. Expect the Steelers to give him a little more rope against the L.A. Chargers with a full week of practice under his belt. He'll only have value while Rudolph is out, but could be a starter in 2-QB or QB-flex leagues.

RB Benny Snell, Pittsburgh Steelers ($2). The Steelers have a similar situation at running back with Jaylen Samuels injuring his knee on Sunday. Although James Connor will likely get an even larger share of the workload, Snell will take over the change-of-pace role.

WR Byron Pringle, Kansas City Chiefs ($2). Don’t read too much into the stats Pringle put up on Sunday. Playing in place of an injured Sammy Watkins, he caught six passes for 103 yards and a touchdown. The Chiefs offense can turn just about anyone on the roster into a star, but Watkins – and possibly Tyreek Hill – could be back this week.

Potential QB streamers: Jimmy Garoppolo, San Francisco 49ers (at L.A. Rams); Gardner Minshew, Jacksonville Jaguars (vs. N.O.); Kyle Allen, Carolina Panthers (at T.B.); Andy Dalton, Cincinnati Bengals (at Bal.).

Follow USA TODAY Sports' Steve Gardner on Twitter @SteveAGardner.

If you love talking football, we have the perfect spot for you. Join our Facebook Group, The Ruling Off the Field, to engage in friendly debate and conversation with fellow football fans and our NFL insiders.
description: There's room for one more receiver in the Los Angeles Rams' pass-happy offense; injuries open up short-term spots in New York Giants' lineup.
